title: Teaching
text:
I currently teach courses in causal inference (MF9570), survival analysis (e.g. MF9510), and introductory statistics (e.g. MF9130), mainly at the PhD program at the Faculty of Medicine, University of Oslo.
In 2024 I held an online ISCB course in biostatistics together with Ruth Keogh on causal inference for time-to-event outcomes with practical applications in R, which might be repeated in the future (in some format).

title: Research
text:
My main research interests are causal inference and time-to-event analysis. In particular, I am interested in methods for estimating the effects of time-varying treatments, time-dependent confounding and other sources of bias in longitudinal settings, time-to-event data, competing risk and multi-state modelling. I also have an interest in studies of infectious diseases and the estimation of treatment effects in such settings, and I have done some work on excess mortality estimation, infectious disease surveillance and infectious disease modelling.
I am interested in applications using both randomised and observational data, and in particular event history data constructed from linked clinical and population-wide registries. I am currently involved in various collaborative projects, e.g. on the effects of rehabilitation and pain medication on patient outcomes after traumatic injury with researchers at the Oslo University Hospital, and on the effects of rehabilitation and workplace initiatives on long-term sick leave and work-related outcomes with researchers at the National Institute of Occupational Health in Norway, with funding from the Research Council of Norway and the Institute of Basic Medical Sciences, University of Oslo. Through my work at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health I’m involved in projects on the estimation of vaccine effects from observational data.
See my Google Scholar profile for publications.

title: Jon Michael Gran
text:
Professor of biostatistics at the Oslo Centre of Biostatistics and Epidemiology, Department of Biostatistics, University of Oslo, working on causal inference and survival/event history analysis.
I currently also hold a 20% position at the Department of Method Development and Analytics, Division of Infection Control and Environmental Health, at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health, and I’m an associate editor in Biometrika.
See my web pages at the University of Oslo and the pages of our causal inference and survival analysis group.
